speaker: Paul Noble
text: Okay. [laughs] "He has" in French is?

speaker: Marion
text: Il a.

speaker: Marion
text: Il a.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How would you say, "He has prepared the coffee for me?"

speaker: Marion
text: Il a préparé le café pour moi.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: "She has" in French is?

speaker: Marion
text: Elle a. Elle a.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: You may be familiar, there's a, a woman's magazine called "Elle", which means "she". So if you're familiar with that, that might help you remember it.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How would you say, "She has prepared the coffee for me"?

speaker: Marion
text: Elle a préparé le café pour moi.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: The word for "your" in French, "your," is?

speaker: Marion
text: Votre.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So for example, to say "your mother," you would say?

speaker: Marion
text: Votre mère. Votre mère.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So how would you say, "Your mother has prepared the coffee"?

speaker: Marion
text: Votre mère a préparé le café.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So as you can see, in English we would say "she has," which is?

speaker: Marion
text: Elle a.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: And so to say "your mother has," you'll say?

speaker: Marion
text: Votre mère a.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So again, how would you say, "Your mother has prepared the coffee"?

speaker: Marion
text: Votre mère a préparé le café.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: How would you say, "Your mother has visited the park"?

speaker: Marion
text: Votre mère a visité le parc.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Now make sure to pronounce the word for "has" very clearly as?

speaker: Marion
text: A.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So it's actually spelt with just an "a", but the "a" in French is pronounced much more as a sort of an "ah" sound.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So not "a" like in English, or "ay", but more of an "ah".

speaker: Paul Noble
text: One more time, "Your mother has visited the park."

speaker: Marion
text: Votre mère a visité le parc.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Good.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Now, if "your mother" is?

speaker: Marion
text: Votre mère.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: It should be relatively easy to realize that "your father" is?

speaker: Marion
text: Votre père.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: One's spelt with an M as in "mama", and one's spelt with a P as in "papa" or something like that. So they're very similar. One is an M, one is a P. It's common through many languages.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So again, "your father" is?

speaker: Marion
text: Votre père.

speaker: Paul Noble
text: Okay, assuming there's been some sort of disagreement, how would you say, "Your mother has visited the park. Your father has visited the Louvre."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: So, "Your mother has visited the park."

speaker: Paul Noble
text: "Your father has visited the Louvre."

speaker: Marion
text: Votre mère a visité le parc. Votre père a visité le Louvre.
